awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Coffee Bean Conversion as a Direct Additive Flavoring to Food and Beverage Products
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development a coffee-sourced food and drink additive product to provide an alternative to conventional methods of achieving coffee flavor. Current methods begin with brewed coffee drink as a food additive precursor while using added chemicals to achieve the desired color and flavor in food and beverage products. The proposed technology preserves larger amounts of caffeine and antioxidants as compared with current technology, while enhancing key volatile compounds for superior color, flavor, and aroma.  The goal is to provide food product companies with a more sustainable, accessible, and healthier alternative to conventional methods for achieving coffee flavor. The proposed technology may be an attractive option for food product companies as it will help them appeal to consumers that are growing increasingly health and environmentally conscious.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a technology for conversion of whole roasted coffee beans to achieve coffee flavor in food and beverage products.  Current technologies are based on water-extracted brewed coffee that is spray dried, concentrated, or freeze dried.  The proposed process involves converting the entire roasted coffee bean into an ultra-ground, one-ingredient flavoring agent that may be used as a direct additive in food and beverage products to achieve coffee flavor with natural coloring.  Unlike current methods for achieving coffee flavor, this process eliminates significant water consumption as well as the spent coffee ground waste stream, making it a sustainable alternative to traditional methods. In addition, the proposed process has been shown to yield maximum nutritional content, enhances key volatile compounds for taste, aroma, and color, and reduces a number of undesirable volatile compounds that result from current processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of our I-Corps project interviews were to ascertain the viability of our technology by interviewing food and beverage industry professionals directly impacted by coffee flavor technology.  Every cup of coffee derives its flavor, aroma, and physiological benefits directly from the coffee bean. Yet, coffee-flavored food and beverage utilize derivatives of brewed coffee, not the bean itself to impart these characteristics, thus losing many key, beneficial components present in natural coffee beans.  Complē Coffee developed a unique process to create a novel food ingredient directly from the roasted coffee bean.  This low moisture powder, composed exclusively of coffee bean material, may be directly added during the batching sequence of food manufacturing to achieve more authentic coffee flavor, color, aroma, and its full nutrient components.  Our interviews discovered how traditional ingredients for food flavorings in the form of coffee concentrates, extracts, and instant coffee particles are utilized during food manufacture.  Additionally, we uncovered nutritional benefits of polyphenols, caffeine and multiple oil-based compounds are significantly limited in current ingredient offerings.

 

Coffee is the second largest traded commodity in the world, only trailing oil as the most valuable commodity.  Nearly half of all coffee beans are processed for the soluble coffee market consisting of instant coffee, coffee concentrates and extracts.  The conventional manufacturing process for instant coffee, coffee concentrates and extracts create a waste stream of spent coffee grounds representing greater than 60% of the initial coffee bean.  Accompanying the spent coffee grounds within the waste stream are an abundance of polyphenols, caffeine, and coffee oils of significant physiological value. Compounding the issues of the environmental waste stream, thermal energy requirements to produce instant coffee are estimated to be one of the highest in the food industry at greater than 35 MJ/kg of product.  Additionally, instant coffee production utilizes very high rates of water which, combined with the other sustainability challenges.

 

Our interviews discovered that Complē Coffee’s patent-pending process has industrial benefits, we found that food and beverage professionals noted it has benefits of a zero-waste, clean label replacement for existing industry technology that was previously unavailable. The utilization of minimal electrical energy and zero water within the process provides the status of the most environmentally sustainable coffee ingredient process available.  Additional process trials are needed to bolster initial successful applications in dairy, bakery and chocolate products including flavored milks, ice creams, nutrition bars, and chocolate candy bars.
